reasons_to_visit.details: March in Santorini brings mild, sunny days (average highs 16–18 °C) ideal for cliff‑side walks in Fira and Oia without summer crowds.
Early spring sees the vineyards around Pyrgos and Megalochori begin to green. Great time for scenic drives and photos of blossoming bougainvillea.
Most hotels and restaurants still offer off‑season rates. UNESCO sites like Ancient Thera and Akrotiri are virtually empty, giving you the run of the ruins.
On March 25th, Fira Town hosts patriotic parades and church services—an authentic glimpse into local culture with fewer crowds than on larger islands.
Depending on the Orthodox calendar, Santorini villages may hold Apokries events or kite‑flying on beaches (e.g., Perissa) for Clean Monday, accompanied by Lenten treats.
Cooler temperatures make hiking the Fira–Oia trail or climbing to Profitis Ilias monastery comfortable—and perfect for sunrise or sunset photography.

reasons_to_reconsider.details: March can bring sudden showers and breezy caldera winds. Pack layers, waterproof jacket, and be ready for variable conditions.
Night‑time lows around 10–12 °C can feel chilly on a terrace. Some restaurants and bars in Oia may still be closed until Easter.

reasons_to_reconsider.reason: Sea Still Too Cold for Swimming
reasons_to_reconsider.details: Sea temperatures average around 16–17 °C, generally too crisp for most swimmers without wetsuits.
Inter‑island ferries and cruise operators run reduced timetables; day‑trips to Thirassia or volcano tours may be less frequent.
Many hotels and venues outside the caldera rim (e.g., Emporio, Akrotiri village) remain closed or on minimal winter schedules.
Local crews begin spring maintenance—vineyard pruning, road repairs—leading to occasional detours or dust on backroads.

weather.precipitation: Moderate chance of brief rain showers; sunny intervals common. Breezy afternoons along the caldera.
weather.general_tips: Pack versatile layers: t‑shirts, light sweater, windbreaker, waterproof jacket. Comfortable walking shoes are a must.

tourism_level.crowds: Low—Ancient Thera and Akrotiri nearly empty. Fira and Oia quiet outside weekends.
tourism_level.pricing: Off‑season rates on hotels and car rentals; restaurants may run special menus to attract early guests.
tourism_level.overall_atmosphere: Calm, reflective, and authentic—ideal for those seeking solitude and local life before the rush.

events_holidays.name: Carnival (Apokries) Events
events_holidays.description: Some villages host small Carnival parades, costume parties, and tsiknopempti grilling events.
events_holidays.notes: Check local taverna noticeboards or ask your host for exact dates.

events_holidays.name: Clean Monday (Kathara Deftera)
events_holidays.description: Kite‑flying and Lenten picnics on beaches like Perissa or Kamari, accompanied by savory Lenten dishes.
events_holidays.notes: Public holiday—some businesses may close; ideal day for outdoor fun if weather permits.

unique_experiences.description: Join locals and families flying kites on the black‑sand shore to celebrate Clean Monday.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Bring your own kite or buy one locally. Dress warmly for coastal breezes.

unique_experiences.description: Tour the Bronze‑Age ruins at a leisurely pace without tour‑group crowds.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Arrive at opening (8 AM); combine with a visit to the nearby Red Beach cliff viewpoint.

unique_experiences.description: Walk or drive up to the 565 m summit for panoramic island views and spring wildflowers.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Wear sturdy shoes; bring water and light layers for winds at elevation.

unique_experiences.description: Delve into Akrotiri’s artifacts and island history in a warm indoor setting.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Allow 1–2 hours; combines well with a café lunch in Fira.

weather.precipitation: Rain showers become less frequent; sunnier and slightly warmer days emerge.
weather.general_tips: Lighten layers as temperatures rise; sunscreen becomes more important. Still bring a windproof jacket.

tourism_level.crowds: Shoulder season picks up—Fira weekends busier, but caldera trails still spacious.
tourism_level.pricing: Rates inch upward toward Easter; mid‑week deals may still exist.
tourism_level.overall_atmosphere: Spring energy builds—vineyards green, terraces reopen, and local life feels vibrant.

events_holidays.name: Greek Independence Day
events_holidays.description: Parades, church services, and festive gatherings in Fira Town’s central square.
events_holidays.notes: Public holiday—many shops/museums close; arrive early to secure parade‑viewing spot.

unique_experiences.activity: Watch Independence Day Parade in Fira
unique_experiences.description: See local schools, military bands, and island associations march in celebration.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Arrive by 9 AM; roads close along the route. Dress for brisk morning air.

unique_experiences.description: Rent a car and capture images of blossoming vine rows, windmills, and white‑washed villages.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Check road conditions; some backroads may be dusty or under repair.

unique_experiences.description: Arrive before dawn to watch the pink‑hued caldera light up as the sun rises—few tourists attempt this.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Bring a headlamp and coffee; paths can be rocky and dark.

unique_experiences.description: Taste Santorini’s volcanic wines in a historic cliff‑side winery with sweeping caldera views.
unique_experiences.practical_tips: Book ahead; small‑group tours include cellar visit and tasting flight.
